stem: The nurse is caring for a client with a T6 spinal cord injury who is experiencing manifestations of autonomic dysreflexia. Which interventions are MOST appropriate for the nurse to implement? Select all that apply.

itemContext.sbar: S: Mr. Jameson Blake, a 48-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, is reporting a severe headache and blurred vision at 14:30. He's also diaphoretic and anxious. A: His BP is 210/110 mmHg, and heart rate is 52 bpm. He has nasal congestion. He reports having a full bladder sensation. He had a bowel movement this morning but it was small and hard. He is on a bowel management program. B: Admitted three weeks ago following a motor vehicle accident resulting in T6 spinal cord injury. He has been stable, participating in rehabilitation. He uses an intermittent catheterization program every 4 hours and stool softeners daily. P: I'm concerned about autonomic dysreflexia. I need an order to catheterize him immediately and check for bowel impaction. I will continue to monitor his blood pressure and heart rate every 5 minutes.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: WBC: 7.8 x 10^9/L, Hemoglobin: 14.2 g/dL, Platelets: 250 x 10^9/L, Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.2 mEq/L, Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL, BUN: 15 mg/dL, Urine Analysis pending.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Docusate 100 mg PO daily, PRN for constipation. Ondansetron 4mg IV PRN for nausea. Hydralazine 10mg IV PRN for BP >180/100 mmHg.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 14:30: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 98% on room air, Temp 37.2°C (99°F).

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed promotes orthostatic hypotension, which helps to lower the blood pressure. Assessing the client for bladder distention is crucial as urinary retention is a common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia. Catheterizing the client as prescribed will relieve bladder pressure. Loosening any tight clothing will reduce external stimuli that can exacerbate the condition. Monitoring blood pressure every 5 minutes allows for close observation of the client's response to interventions.
rationale.incorrect: Administering oxygen is not a primary intervention for autonomic dysreflexia unless the client's oxygen saturation is compromised. While it is important to document the findings, it is not an initial intervention when the client is experiencing a hypertensive crisis.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention.
Always assess for and address the most common triggers first: bladder and bowel distention.
Elevate the head of the bed as the initial intervention to lower blood pressure.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the blood pressure reading and immediately selecting the antihypertensive medication without addressing the underlying cause of the autonomic dysreflexia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize identifying and alleviating the trigger for the autonomic dysreflexia before administering medications. Remember ABC's, but also think about the underlying cause of the patient's distress.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion: S: Search for the cause (bladder, bowel, skin). I: Immediate action (elevate head, loosen clothing). T: Take blood pressure. U: Utilize medications if needed. P: Prevent recurrence.

options.text: Administer oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula.
Elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees.
Assess the client for bladder distention.
Document the findings in the electronic health record.
